sample_docs: Clinton Won Last Night's Debate, According to Communication Science Last night's debate — the first official showdown between presidential candidates Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton — was, as the GOP candidate would say, a huge event. The only certainty, it seemed, was that anything could happen. However, there was a consensus among reporters that, in order to win the debate, each candidate would have to achieve a certain set of goals. Trump would have to reign in his infamous bombastic nature and approach the debate coolly, rationally, and substantively. Clinton, would have to ease off her traditionally calculated approach and connect with her audience in an engaging, authentic manner she has yet to achieve. In the hours following the event, pundits and pollsters analyzed each candidate's performance from countless angles, and QC was right there with them. We used our language analytics platform to identify which candidate had achieved those critical goals during the first faceoff. Read our full analysis to find out how they performed. You can also find QC's coverage of the first debate in Bloomberg Politics: Clinton Excels in Debate by Laying Traps on Trump's Temperament To find out how Quantified Communications can help ensure your company's communications are best-in-class, email us at info@quantifiedcommunications.com . Our Favorite Stories of Data Enhancing Lives A hand-curated newsletter from the Quantified Communications research team, bringing you the most up-to-date and fascinating insights in people, behavioral, and communication analytics from the past month. QC's Communication Best Practices Theresa May, Prime Minister of the United Kingdom The Event: Last week, Theresa May officially notified the EU of Britain's decision to withraw. In her coinciding speech to Parliament, May urged the country to strive for unity during this time of change. Best-in-Class Example of Optimism Why It's Great: Though the subject of her address was a bitterly divisive political issue, the Prime Minister delivered a hopeful message about Britain's future. Her optimism was underscored by her emphasis on inclusion and unity. Communication research has found that audiences are more likely to be persuaded if they feel personally involved in a message , and May's focus on "we" and "us" likely helped British citizens feel as though the bright future belonged not just to Parliament, but to the community as a whole. This Month in Communication Analytics You, Next Time You Take the Stage Infographic: 10 Stats You Need to Know to Give a Great Presentation >> There's plenty to keep in mind as you prepare for your next presentation. We combed through years of communication data and audience research to identify 10 stats that will help you bring down the house. Uri Hasson, Neuroscientist, Princeton University Hard Data Shows This Soft Skill Will Make You 35 Percent More Persuasive >> In his recent article for Inc.com, Carmine Gallo combines Uri Hasson's research on brain mirroring with QC data and best practices from TED to demonstrate exactly why storytelling is so important for persuading audiences. Natalie Clarkson, Content Executive, Virgin.com How Could Your Storytelling Be Better? >> Speaking of storytelling, this quick, 5-question quiz explores communicatoion findings from universities and institutions across the world. How much do you know about storytelling? This Month in Behavioral Analytics Monisha Perkash, CEO & Co-Founder, Lumo Wearable Technology Tells You How You're Doing, and Where You Can Improve >> When Fitbit brought wearable tech to the mainstream we were obsessed with the amount of data it could capture and report. But now, new wearable developments make it clear that consumers want more than data — they want action plans. Pia Orrenius, Economist, Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas Where American Income Has Grown Most Over 25 Years >> This visualization of average income growth uses data from the Quarterly Census of Employment and Wages to show how the booms and busts of the past 25 years have impacted U.S. wages from county to county. Steve Bate, Paralympic Gold Medalist Big Data Analytics in Sports >> Once upon a time, athletes had to train in labs if they wanted more insightful data than RBIs or rushing yards. But today, wearable tech and big data empower athletes to track health and performance in competitive conditions. Play ball. This Month in People Analytics Richard Culatta, Rhode Island Chief Innovation Officer Will Personalized Learning Become the New Normal? >> Personalized learning uses technology and data to tailor classroom education to individual students' needs, and Rhode Island school districts are leading the way in implementing these new, data-driven programs. Yaacov Cohen, CEO, Harmon.ie The Great Enterprise Productivity Debate >> With organizations employing countless apps to enhance productivity, many professionals are overwhelmed by the "always on" culture and the neverending flow of notifications. One tech company is using machine learning to tackle the problem. Michael Gretczko, Principal, Deloitte Is HR Data More Valuble to a Business than Financial Data? >> Humans (and the IP they produce) are the only assets at many tech-driven companies, so it's no surprise employers are eager to gather HR data. But where is the line between supporting employees and invading their privacy? Curated by Sarah Weber, Noah Zandan, and the Quantified Communications Team We'd love to hear your feedback. Feel free to send comments or questions to sarah.weber@quantifiedcommunications.com . I f you like what you've read, use the buttons below to share. If someone forwarded this to you, to subscribe . Our Favorite Stories of Data Enhancing Lives A hand-curated newsletter from the Quantified Communications research team, bringing you the latest and most fascinating insights in people, behavioral, and communication analytics. The Latest in People Analytics Neil Levy, Deputy Director, Oxford Centre for Neuroethics Military Tests Electrical Brain Stimulation to Enhance Skills >> US Military scientists have developed electrical brain stimulators designed to boost performance in high-pressure roles. Neil Levy weighs in on the safety, ethics, and regulations of the technology. Jason Dana, Management Professor, Yale University Job Interviews Are Useless >> When faced with big decisions, we've all been taught to "go with our gut." But for hiring decisions, research shows employers would do better to rely on data from intelligence and aptitude tests, rather than interview-based instincts. Kieran Snyder, Founder, Textio; Joelle Emerson, Founder, Paradigm These Jobs are More Likely to Be Filled by Women >> New research from job post optimization company Textio, and diversity consulting firm Paradigm, finds women are more likely to lean in when jobs are described in of growth, rather than fixed traits. The Latest in Behavioral Analytics Jason Karaian, Senior Europe Correspondent, Quartz How Long Before We See Santa in July? >> These days, it seems we barely clear Halloween before Christmas decorations start to appear. Quartz's Christmas Creep Calculator predicts how long it will be before we're celebrating Christmas in July. Bah Humbug! Neal Myrick, Tableau; Jeff Bernson, PATH Tableau and PATH Fight Malaria with Data Analytics >> In a campaign called Vizualize No Malaria, global health nonprofit PATH and data visualization company Tableau have teamed up to help Zambia achieve its goal of eliminating malaria by 2020. Neil Grimmer, CEO, Habit A Meal Kit Designs Your Diet By Analyzing Your Blood >> The latest meal delivery company, funded by Campbell's Soup and launching next year, will use body metric data and home blood-testing kits to develop custom meal plans tailored to each customer's specific nutritional needs. Bon appetit! The Latest in Communication Analytics Gregory Lee, CEO, Samsung Electronics Samsung's Galaxy Note7 Apology Rings Loud and Clear >> Samsung's much-anticipated Galaxy Note7 went on sale this summer, but was quickly pulled off the market when batteries began exploding in users' pockets. How did the CEO's apology letter compare to recent crisis communications? Nate Silver, Founder, FiveThirtyEight Personal Communication Analytics as an Alternative Way to Predict Public Support, and Maybe Even Elections >> When Silver predicted Clinton's chances of winning at only 71.4%, he was ridiculed by the rest of the pollsters, who had her pegged as a sure thing. But as results rolled in on election night, it became all too clear: our prediction models are deeply flawed. Mark McKinnon, Producer, Showtime's The Circus In a Political Game All About Storytelling, Which Candidate Used Narrative to Get Ahead? >> As the nation looks back on the months of campaigning that led to last week's surprising results, we're revisiting perhaps the most important communication skill candidates can have, and how it helped Trump rally voters from the start. The shout-out goes to... Hubert Joly, CEO, Best Buy The Event: In his remarks at this fall's French American Chamber of Commerce gala , Mr. Joly outlines the "Five Bs" of leadership. Why it's great: Mr. Joly's remarks scored in the 90th percentile for authenticity, as he addressed the crowd in the same tone he might use to speak with a friend over coffee. QC coach Maegan Stephens, Ph.D. says one of the keys to achieving this level of authenticity is to rehearse from an outline and learn the content rather than relying on a script, which can make speakers sound stilted as they focus on recalling each word instead of conveying the key points. Did you come across a fantastic talk this week? Tell us about it, and you could be featured in the next QC Shout-Outs! Curated by Sarah Weber, Noah Zandan, and the Quantified Communications Team We'd love to hear your feedback. Feel free to send comments or questions to sarah.weber@quantifiedcommunications.com . I f you like what you've read, use the buttons below to share. If someone forwarded this to you, to subscribe .
